Motivation Erik Wilde (@dret): XML Namespaces: Identifying XML Vocabularies

(6) Problem 1: Across XML Documents

  • Names in XML documents can conflict across documents
<product>
  <name>Product Name</name>
</product>
  • naming-xml-1-plain.xml
<customer>
  <name>Customer Name</name>
</customer>
  • naming-xml-2-plain.xml
  • Namespaces turn local names into globally unique names
<product xmlns="http://example.org/product">
  <name>Product Name</name>
</product>
  • naming-xml-1-xmlns.xml
<customer xmlns="http://example.org/customer">
  <name>Customer Name</name>
</customer>
  • naming-xml-2-xmlns.xml


Motivation Erik Wilde (@dret): XML Namespaces: Identifying XML Vocabularies

(7) Problem 2: Composing XML Documents

  • How to keep names separate when combining documents
<product xmlns="http://example.org/product">
  <name>Product Name</name>
</product>
  • naming-xml-1-xmlns.xml
<customer xmlns="http://example.org/customer">
  <name>Customer Name</name>
</customer>
  • naming-xml-2-xmlns.xml
<product xmlns="http://example.org/product">
  <name>Product Name</name>
  <reviews>
    <review>
      <customer xmlns="http://example.org/customer">
        <name>Customer Name</name>
      </customer>
    </review>
  </reviews>
</product>
  • naming-xml-3-xmlns.xml


Motivation Erik Wilde (@dret): XML Namespaces: Identifying XML Vocabularies

(8) What do XML Names mean?

  • XML documents use names (elements and attributes)
  • Names are supposed to identify meaningful chunks of data
  • XML schemas (such as DTD or XSD) define allowed elements/attributes
  • XML has been designed to support the combination of schemas


Motivation Erik Wilde (@dret): XML Namespaces: Identifying XML Vocabularies

(9) GPS Data in XML 

<gpx version="1.1" xmlns="http://www.topografix.com/GPX/1/1" xmlns:TPE="http://www.garmin.com/xmlschemas/TrackPointExtension/v1">
  <metadata>
    <time>2020-02-25T13:26:26.000Z</time>
  </metadata>
  <trk>
    <name>Central Park</name>
    <desc>Easy morning run in central park, with no sunshine today but at least it was dry and not too cold; explored some more of the countless small trails north of the lake.</desc>
    <type>Running</type>
    <trkseg>
      <trkpt lat="40.762783326208591461181640625" lon="-73.97837824188172817230224609375">
        <ele>21</ele>
        <time>2020-02-25T13:26:26.000Z</time>
        <extensions>
          <TPE:TrackPointExtension>
            <TPE:atemp>27.0</TPE:atemp>
            <TPE:hr>53</TPE:hr>
            <TPE:cad>0</TPE:cad>
          </TPE:TrackPointExtension>
        </extensions>
      </trkpt>
  • central-park.gpx (line 2-21)


Motivation Erik Wilde (@dret): XML Namespaces: Identifying XML Vocabularies

(10) Name Spaces

  • XML's main concepts (elements/attributes) are using names
  • Names are an important form of identification
  • Names in XML are not suitable for (globally unique) identification
    • They are local to where they are used
    • If the context is uniquely identified, so are the names
  • Name Spaces: Put names into spaces
    • How to identify the name space? Identifiers on the Web are URIs!


Motivation Erik Wilde (@dret): XML Namespaces: Identifying XML Vocabularies

(11) XML Namespace Definition

  • XML elements and attributes can be associated with a namespace
  • XML namespaces are identified by URIs
  • All relevant XML technologies are based on and supporting XML namespaces


Motivation Erik Wilde (@dret): XML Namespaces: Identifying XML Vocabularies

(12) The URI Instinct

  • Namespace names are URIs
  • People assume that URIs point to Web pages
    • A namespace name may point to a Web page
    • It may also have no Web page associated with it
  • People expect namespace URIs to provide useful information
    • Friendly namespaces provide HTML pages (XHTML [http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml] and XSLT [http://www.w3.org/1999/XSL/Transform])
    • Some namespaces just give you the schema (SOAP [http://www.w3.org/2001/12/soap-envelope])
    • Unfriendly namespaces may return 404 or use inaccessible URI schemes
    • They all are correct, because all that matters is the namespace name/URI
  • Namespaces are always recognized by comparing URIs


Motivation Erik Wilde (@dret): XML Namespaces: Identifying XML Vocabularies

(13) Simpler Than You Think

  • XML namespaces put XML names in spaces
  • Each space is identified by a URI
  • Understanding a namespace is out of scope
  • Make no assumptions about namespace URIs and all is good


Using XML Namespaces

Outline (Using XML Namespaces)

  1. Introduction [2]

Using XML Namespaces Erik Wilde (@dret): XML Namespaces: Identifying XML Vocabularies

(15) XML Namespaces Basics

  • XML Namespaces are declared using xmlns attributes
  • Each declaration declares the default namespace or a prefix
    • xmlns="" declares the default namespace
    • xmlns:prefix="" declares namespaces prefixes
  • Declarations work in the usual XML tree-oriented way
  • Names (elements/attributes) use namespaces by using a prefix


Using XML Namespaces Erik Wilde (@dret): XML Namespaces: Identifying XML Vocabularies

(16) Example XML Namespace Declarations 

<foo:root xmlns="http://example.org/ns1" xmlns:foo="http://example.org/ns2">
  <bar:element xmlns:bar="http://example.org/ns3">Test</bar:element>
  <element>Demo</element>
</foo:root>
  • namespace-example.xml
  • Three namespaces declared by three xmlns attributes
    • The default namespace and two prefix-associated namespaces
    • Namespaces can be declared on any element in the document
  • Three elements from three different namespaces
    • Having the same local name does not make it the same element


Using XML Namespaces Erik Wilde (@dret): XML Namespaces: Identifying XML Vocabularies

(17) Identical XML Documents 

<document xmlns="http://example.org/demo">
  <title>Namespace Example</title>
</document>
  • namespace-default.xml
<demo:document xmlns:demo="http://example.org/demo">
  <demo:title>Namespace Example</demo:title>
</demo:document>
  • namespace-prefix-1.xml
<irrelevant:document xmlns:irrelevant="http://example.org/demo">
  <irrelevant:title>Namespace Example</irrelevant:title>
</irrelevant:document>
  • namespace-prefix-2.xml


Using XML Namespaces Erik Wilde (@dret): XML Namespaces: Identifying XML Vocabularies

(18) Using Namespaces in Practice

  • Namespaces must be used by comparing URIs
    • Everything else is brittle and can break anytime
    • Prefixes have no effect on a name in an XML namespace
  • Treat prefixes as a representation detail
    • When parsing XML, always use namespace URIs (and not prefixes)
    • When writing XML, create prefixes that are commonly used


Using XML Namespaces Erik Wilde (@dret): XML Namespaces: Identifying XML Vocabularies

(19) XPath for Finding Namespaces

  • //* â select all elements of an XML document
  • namespace-uri() â return the namespace name of a node
  • distinct-values() â return all distinct values of a sequence 
distinct-values(//*/namespace-uri())


Good Practices

Outline (Good Practices)

  1. Introduction [2]
  2. Motivation [8]
  3. Using XML Namespaces [5]
  4. Good Practices [2]
  5. Conclusions [2]
Good Practices Erik Wilde (@dret): XML Namespaces: Identifying XML Vocabularies

(21) Keep it Simple

  • Declare all prefixes on the document element
  • Only declare prefixes that are used in the document
  • Use speaking names for prefixes
    • If you create a namespace also define a preferred prefix


Good Practices Erik Wilde (@dret): XML Namespaces: Identifying XML Vocabularies

(22) Namespaces Anti-Patterns 

<document>
 <prefix:elem xmlns:prefix="http://example.com/ns1"/>
 <prefix:elem xmlns:prefix="http://example.com/ns2"/>
</document>
  • neurotic.xml
<document>
 <prefix1:elem xmlns:prefix1="http://example.com/ns1"/> 
 <prefix2:elem xmlns:prefix2="http://example.com/ns1"/>
</document>
  • borderline.xml

Conclusions Erik Wilde (@dret): XML Namespaces: Identifying XML Vocabularies

(24) XML Needs Namespaces

  • If you do anything with XML, learn namespaces
  • XML namespaces are simpler than most people think
  • All XML technologies are based on XML namespaces
  • Knowing XML namespaces will make your XML life much easier


Conclusions Erik Wilde (@dret): XML Namespaces: Identifying XML Vocabularies
